issue.title: Intermittent hang in FUSE test suites
issue.body:
Sometimes fuse tests don't run, and the process hangs. This is typically resolved by rerunning tup. However,

1) The tests shouldn't hang, so we should find out what is going on. I _think_ the hang occurs on startup before the individual tests are run, rather than e.g. midway through a test. Need to validate this hypothesis.
2) There is a rerun mechanism built into fuse-tests.sh that is intended to workaround the issue, yet it doesn't work, for some unknown reason. It implements retries for the test suite, yet if one fails, they all seem to fail. This is curious, since rerunning `tup` normally fixes it. Perhaps a sleep is needed? In any case, would be better to fix the problem at source.

One reason I've not looked too deeply is that the problem may lie in fuse, tup, bash, or something outside of this code base, and that may be tricky to diagnose.

issue.title: Create docker-worker deprecation decision brief
Take a firefox ci decision task, and work out how to transform it to run under generic-worker
issue.body:
In order to run docker-worker tasks under generic-worker, it is desirable to have the facility to take a docker-worker task, and transform it into a generic-worker task.

This transformation eventually could be performed in several places:
* inside generic-worker itself; first identify that the task has a docker-worker payload, transform it to a native generic-worker format, and then internally execute that, so that to all intents and purposes the task author need not be concerned that the transformation took place
* inside taskgraph; in this case, the better approach is probably to directly generate generic-worker tasks rather than to generate docker-worker as an intermediary step. The task building mechanics used by firefox-ci appears to be [here](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/88f285c5163f73abd209d4f73cfa476660351982/taskcluster/gecko_taskgraph/transforms/task.py#323-821)
* inside a standalone tool that can be used from multiple contexts, such as inside a task itself

We have decided that a transformation process is more desirable than hardcoding the interpretation of a docker-worker payload inside generic-worker directly, since that is likely to introduce a larger code footprint of greater complexity. It also would not be so flexible, and make it harder to move this logic elsewhere at a later point in time, and require worker updates to all affected worker pools any time changes are desired.

There is also the possibility of introducing the transformation in more than one place, such as in taskgraph and inside the worker directly, to ease the migration of tasks in real world deployments from docker-worker to generic-worker. Potentially once all tasks are migrated, and direct execution of docker-worker style task payloads are no longer required, the capability can be deprecated and eventually removed from one or more sources, but e.g. the standalone tool may still be useful for users that wish not to migrate. None of this _needs to be_ decided now. We can first determine what the transformation steps are, write code that can transform the payload, inject this into the places it makes sense to do so (bullet points above) and then review the situation in the future to see if it makes sense to simplify by removing support in one or more places this transformation capability was added.

In order to know how to reliably transform task payloads from one format to the other, the first step is to work out how to transform a single real-world docker-worker task the equivalent generic-worker task, and make sure it works. That is what this github issue is for.

The following is an explanation of the transformation that was performed.

1. Give the container a name, because we are going to extract artifacts from it, so after it has run, we need a reference to its name to be able to copy artifacts onto host. I just generated a slug id for the name of the container (`Twy9U8HtRD2X_m_XCahbEQ`), it can be anything though.
1. Since the `osGroups` feature isn't implemented on Linux yet, I’m running with provisionerId/workerType `proj-taskcluster/gw-ci-ubuntu-18-04` which runs task commands as `root`. Since this mounts cache directories as the task user rather than root, I explicity `chown` the cache directory/directories as `root:root`. When we implement `osGroups` feature, we will add the `docker` group to the task, add the scope to allow its use, and we won’t need the `chown` command, and we won’t need to run on `gw-ci-ubuntu-18-04` since tasks won't need to run as root user anymore.
1. We capture the exit code of the docker container, and don’t exit if it fails, so that we can extract artifact files/directories onto host before task completes. We then `exit ${exit_code}`  in the bash script which wraps the docker command so that original exit code is recorded for task command.
1. After task runs, but before exiting with exit code, to extract artifacts from docker container we run a `docker cp` command for each artifact file/directory declared in the payload.
1. We delete the docker container we created after extracting what we need - although technically not needed, as generic-worker cleans up the task user after the task completes anyway. However, explicitly doing so provides greater clearity about intent.
1. Caches are mounted with `-v` options of `docker run` command.
1. In order for the task commands to have network connectivity to the taskcluster-proxy service started by generic-worker, we add `--add-host=taskcluster:127.0.0.1 --net=host` to the docker run command so that name resolution succeeds.
1. Every environment variable declared in payload is passed into docker run command via `-e <envVar>=<value>` arguments. In addition, the docker-worker managed env vars (except for `TASKCLUSTER_WORKER_LOCATION` - see next point) are also passed through (`RUN_ID`, `TASKCLUSTER_PROXY_URL`, `TASKCLUSTER_ROOT_URL`, `TASK_ID`).
1. `TASKCLUSTER_WORKER_LOCATION` seems to be broken in worker-runner since https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/pull/3686 so we may need to fix that. Decision task can however survive without `TASKCLUSTER_WORKER_LOCATION`.
1. Payload property artifacts has slightly different format under generic-worker (list, not dictionary) - so the artifact object is transformed into a list.
1. Payload property caches feature of docker-worker is mapped to mounts feature of generic-worker, again with slightly different syntax.
1. When docker image is a reference to an image on a docker registry, this reference can be used directly in the `docker run` command as in this case. If the docker payload instead uses a different format to specify docker image (such as a task artifact for a `docker load` command) then we’ll need to transform that slightly differently. This task doesn't cover that case.
1. docker-worker scopes for using caches need to be converted to the equivalent generic-worker scopes to mount the cache under generic-worker.

issue.title: "certificate has expired" sentry alerts for github service
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Sentry issue: https://sentry.io/organizations/mozilla/issues/3555315507/?project=6459385

Exception "certificate has expired" being raised by github service when trying to fetch live log of a task.

**Expected behavior**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen. -->

**Taskcluster version**
Sentry reports this started in taskcluster release 44.20.0.

**Screenshots**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/190790/196697296-27e61dfd-d7fe-4969-b554-5fbd781e1932.png)

**Additional context**
An abbreviated log was added to the github checks output that contained the last lines of the log in release 44.20.0. This retrieved the task log from task artifact `public/logs/live.log`. While the task is running, this artifact will redirect to a live http feed on the worker, which in the case of docker-worker, will be a url with a hostname provided by the stateless dns service. Docker worker configures these hostnames to be valid for the [max run time of the task](https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/blob/ec95016e24808759f3df3db5b6173fc6371a76e7/workers/docker-worker/src/task.js#L790). Under normal operation, the task will complete within the max run time, and replace the live log artifact with a redirect artifact to the backing log. However, since there is no leniency in the expiration of the DNS record, presumably if the livelog url is queried immediately after the expiration of the dns record, but before docker worker has had the chance to upload the backing log and publish the redirect artifact for the livelog, the request will result in an expired certificate. This could also happen if docker-worker hangs for some reason, and does not publish the backing log.

In all cases it is probably desirable to only fetch the log once the task has completed, which is perhaps already the case. In this case, fetching the backing log is desirable, since it should contain the entire log, and only exist if the task has completed. This also avoids that the github service makes active connections to running workers, but instead retrieves artifacts directly from artifact storage (currently, aws s3). Live logs are really only meant to serve users directly, rather than backend services.

pull_request.title: Add build-essential to ubuntu 18.04 and upgrade go and TC versions to latest

review.body:
Thanks for this Boris!

I have some thoughts:

1) It might be that we can remove go in the base image, since our tasks install it. I wonder if the linking problem that we had was because of something that was getting picked up from the go1.18.1 host installation, that conflicted with the go1.19.2 installation of the task. We can talk about this, as there are arguments on both sides worth exploring.
2) Maybe we don't need build-essential, but just gcc - although maybe also nice to have a comprehensive set of tools by default. Again it is quite a nuanced issue, because on one hand it is nice to have reasonable defaults for installed tools, but on the other hand it encourages tasks not to declare dependencies and pin them, so system updates can break user tasks.
3) There is an update to a relman-specific image set, which probably isn't used by the taskcluster project. That is probably a good thing, we just need to make sure we let the team (Release Management - relman) know that we are patching their base images, and keep an eye on their tasks, to see if they start failing after this change.
4) For each of the bootstrap scripts that have been updated, we should build the new machine images (run `imageset.sh` script) so that the latest version in the repository is consistent with the live images. I think this is done for `generic-worker-ubuntu-20-04` but perhaps not for the other image sets yet?

Anyway this is a great start, and I'm really happy to see you were able to build new images successfully. Let's discuss the options for the above points when we next meet up.

Thanks Boris!

issue.title: Intermittent hang in FUSE test suites
issue.body:
Sometimes fuse tests don't run, and the process hangs. This is typically resolved by rerunning tup. However,

1) The tests shouldn't hang, so we should find out what is going on. I _think_ the hang occurs on startup before the individual tests are run, rather than e.g. midway through a test. Need to validate this hypothesis.
2) There is a rerun mechanism built into fuse-tests.sh that is intended to workaround the issue, yet it doesn't work, for some unknown reason. It implements retries for the test suite, yet if one fails, they all seem to fail. This is curious, since rerunning `tup` normally fixes it. Perhaps a sleep is needed? In any case, would be better to fix the problem at source.

One reason I've not looked too deeply is that the problem may lie in fuse, tup, bash, or something outside of this code base, and that may be tricky to diagnose.

comment.body:

./fuse-tests.sh: line 52: kill: (129150) - No such process

issue.title: Create docker-worker deprecation decision brief
Take a firefox ci decision task, and work out how to transform it to run under generic-worker
issue.body:
In order to run docker-worker tasks under generic-worker, it is desirable to have the facility to take a docker-worker task, and transform it into a generic-worker task.

This transformation eventually could be performed in several places:
* inside generic-worker itself; first identify that the task has a docker-worker payload, transform it to a native generic-worker format, and then internally execute that, so that to all intents and purposes the task author need not be concerned that the transformation took place
* inside taskgraph; in this case, the better approach is probably to directly generate generic-worker tasks rather than to generate docker-worker as an intermediary step. The task building mechanics used by firefox-ci appears to be [here](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/88f285c5163f73abd209d4f73cfa476660351982/taskcluster/gecko_taskgraph/transforms/task.py#323-821)
* inside a standalone tool that can be used from multiple contexts, such as inside a task itself

We have decided that a transformation process is more desirable than hardcoding the interpretation of a docker-worker payload inside generic-worker directly, since that is likely to introduce a larger code footprint of greater complexity. It also would not be so flexible, and make it harder to move this logic elsewhere at a later point in time, and require worker updates to all affected worker pools any time changes are desired.

There is also the possibility of introducing the transformation in more than one place, such as in taskgraph and inside the worker directly, to ease the migration of tasks in real world deployments from docker-worker to generic-worker. Potentially once all tasks are migrated, and direct execution of docker-worker style task payloads are no longer required, the capability can be deprecated and eventually removed from one or more sources, but e.g. the standalone tool may still be useful for users that wish not to migrate. None of this _needs to be_ decided now. We can first determine what the transformation steps are, write code that can transform the payload, inject this into the places it makes sense to do so (bullet points above) and then review the situation in the future to see if it makes sense to simplify by removing support in one or more places this transformation capability was added.

In order to know how to reliably transform task payloads from one format to the other, the first step is to work out how to transform a single real-world docker-worker task the equivalent generic-worker task, and make sure it works. That is what this github issue is for.

The following is an explanation of the transformation that was performed.

1. Give the container a name, because we are going to extract artifacts from it, so after it has run, we need a reference to its name to be able to copy artifacts onto host. I just generated a slug id for the name of the container (`Twy9U8HtRD2X_m_XCahbEQ`), it can be anything though.
1. Since the `osGroups` feature isn't implemented on Linux yet, I’m running with provisionerId/workerType `proj-taskcluster/gw-ci-ubuntu-18-04` which runs task commands as `root`. Since this mounts cache directories as the task user rather than root, I explicity `chown` the cache directory/directories as `root:root`. When we implement `osGroups` feature, we will add the `docker` group to the task, add the scope to allow its use, and we won’t need the `chown` command, and we won’t need to run on `gw-ci-ubuntu-18-04` since tasks won't need to run as root user anymore.
1. We capture the exit code of the docker container, and don’t exit if it fails, so that we can extract artifact files/directories onto host before task completes. We then `exit ${exit_code}`  in the bash script which wraps the docker command so that original exit code is recorded for task command.
1. After task runs, but before exiting with exit code, to extract artifacts from docker container we run a `docker cp` command for each artifact file/directory declared in the payload.
1. We delete the docker container we created after extracting what we need - although technically not needed, as generic-worker cleans up the task user after the task completes anyway. However, explicitly doing so provides greater clearity about intent.
1. Caches are mounted with `-v` options of `docker run` command.
1. In order for the task commands to have network connectivity to the taskcluster-proxy service started by generic-worker, we add `--add-host=taskcluster:127.0.0.1 --net=host` to the docker run command so that name resolution succeeds.
1. Every environment variable declared in payload is passed into docker run command via `-e <envVar>=<value>` arguments. In addition, the docker-worker managed env vars (except for `TASKCLUSTER_WORKER_LOCATION` - see next point) are also passed through (`RUN_ID`, `TASKCLUSTER_PROXY_URL`, `TASKCLUSTER_ROOT_URL`, `TASK_ID`).
1. `TASKCLUSTER_WORKER_LOCATION` seems to be broken in worker-runner since https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/pull/3686 so we may need to fix that. Decision task can however survive without `TASKCLUSTER_WORKER_LOCATION`.
1. Payload property artifacts has slightly different format under generic-worker (list, not dictionary) - so the artifact object is transformed into a list.
1. Payload property caches feature of docker-worker is mapped to mounts feature of generic-worker, again with slightly different syntax.
1. When docker image is a reference to an image on a docker registry, this reference can be used directly in the `docker run` command as in this case. If the docker payload instead uses a different format to specify docker image (such as a task artifact for a `docker load` command) then we’ll need to transform that slightly differently. This task doesn't cover that case.
1. docker-worker scopes for using caches need to be converted to the equivalent generic-worker scopes to mount the cache under generic-worker.

issue.title: "certificate has expired" sentry alerts for github service
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Sentry issue: https://sentry.io/organizations/mozilla/issues/3555315507/?project=6459385

Exception "certificate has expired" being raised by github service when trying to fetch live log of a task.

**Expected behavior**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen. -->

**Taskcluster version**
Sentry reports this started in taskcluster release 44.20.0.

**Screenshots**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/190790/196697296-27e61dfd-d7fe-4969-b554-5fbd781e1932.png)

**Additional context**
An abbreviated log was added to the github checks output that contained the last lines of the log in release 44.20.0. This retrieved the task log from task artifact `public/logs/live.log`. While the task is running, this artifact will redirect to a live http feed on the worker, which in the case of docker-worker, will be a url with a hostname provided by the stateless dns service. Docker worker configures these hostnames to be valid for the [max run time of the task](https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/blob/ec95016e24808759f3df3db5b6173fc6371a76e7/workers/docker-worker/src/task.js#L790). Under normal operation, the task will complete within the max run time, and replace the live log artifact with a redirect artifact to the backing log. However, since there is no leniency in the expiration of the DNS record, presumably if the livelog url is queried immediately after the expiration of the dns record, but before docker worker has had the chance to upload the backing log and publish the redirect artifact for the livelog, the request will result in an expired certificate. This could also happen if docker-worker hangs for some reason, and does not publish the backing log.

In all cases it is probably desirable to only fetch the log once the task has completed, which is perhaps already the case. In this case, fetching the backing log is desirable, since it should contain the entire log, and only exist if the task has completed. This also avoids that the github service makes active connections to running workers, but instead retrieves artifacts directly from artifact storage (currently, aws s3). Live logs are really only meant to serve users directly, rather than backend services.

pull_request.title: Add build-essential to ubuntu 18.04 and upgrade go and TC versions to latest

review.body:
Thanks for this Boris!

I have some thoughts:

1) It might be that we can remove go in the base image, since our tasks install it. I wonder if the linking problem that we had was because of something that was getting picked up from the go1.18.1 host installation, that conflicted with the go1.19.2 installation of the task. We can talk about this, as there are arguments on both sides worth exploring.
2) Maybe we don't need build-essential, but just gcc - although maybe also nice to have a comprehensive set of tools by default. Again it is quite a nuanced issue, because on one hand it is nice to have reasonable defaults for installed tools, but on the other hand it encourages tasks not to declare dependencies and pin them, so system updates can break user tasks.
3) There is an update to a relman-specific image set, which probably isn't used by the taskcluster project. That is probably a good thing, we just need to make sure we let the team (Release Management - relman) know that we are patching their base images, and keep an eye on their tasks, to see if they start failing after this change.
4) For each of the bootstrap scripts that have been updated, we should build the new machine images (run `imageset.sh` script) so that the latest version in the repository is consistent with the live images. I think this is done for `generic-worker-ubuntu-20-04` but perhaps not for the other image sets yet?

Anyway this is a great start, and I'm really happy to see you were able to build new images successfully. Let's discuss the options for the above points when we next meet up.

Thanks Boris!

issue.title: Intermittent hang in FUSE test suites
issue.body:
Sometimes fuse tests don't run, and the process hangs. This is typically resolved by rerunning tup. However,

1) The tests shouldn't hang, so we should find out what is going on. I _think_ the hang occurs on startup before the individual tests are run, rather than e.g. midway through a test. Need to validate this hypothesis.
2) There is a rerun mechanism built into fuse-tests.sh that is intended to workaround the issue, yet it doesn't work, for some unknown reason. It implements retries for the test suite, yet if one fails, they all seem to fail. This is curious, since rerunning `tup` normally fixes it. Perhaps a sleep is needed? In any case, would be better to fix the problem at source.

One reason I've not looked too deeply is that the problem may lie in fuse, tup, bash, or something outside of this code base, and that may be tricky to diagnose.

comment.body:
This failure now looks like this:

[1936](https://github.com/spectrum4/spectrum4/actions/runs/3376735928/jobs/5604817005#step:3:1937)
./fuse-tests.sh: line 52: kill: (129150) - No such process
```

issue.title: Create docker-worker deprecation decision brief
Take a firefox ci decision task, and work out how to transform it to run under generic-worker
issue.body:
In order to run docker-worker tasks under generic-worker, it is desirable to have the facility to take a docker-worker task, and transform it into a generic-worker task.

This transformation eventually could be performed in several places:
* inside generic-worker itself; first identify that the task has a docker-worker payload, transform it to a native generic-worker format, and then internally execute that, so that to all intents and purposes the task author need not be concerned that the transformation took place
* inside taskgraph; in this case, the better approach is probably to directly generate generic-worker tasks rather than to generate docker-worker as an intermediary step. The task building mechanics used by firefox-ci appears to be [here](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/88f285c5163f73abd209d4f73cfa476660351982/taskcluster/gecko_taskgraph/transforms/task.py#323-821)
* inside a standalone tool that can be used from multiple contexts, such as inside a task itself

We have decided that a transformation process is more desirable than hardcoding the interpretation of a docker-worker payload inside generic-worker directly, since that is likely to introduce a larger code footprint of greater complexity. It also would not be so flexible, and make it harder to move this logic elsewhere at a later point in time, and require worker updates to all affected worker pools any time changes are desired.

There is also the possibility of introducing the transformation in more than one place, such as in taskgraph and inside the worker directly, to ease the migration of tasks in real world deployments from docker-worker to generic-worker. Potentially once all tasks are migrated, and direct execution of docker-worker style task payloads are no longer required, the capability can be deprecated and eventually removed from one or more sources, but e.g. the standalone tool may still be useful for users that wish not to migrate. None of this _needs to be_ decided now. We can first determine what the transformation steps are, write code that can transform the payload, inject this into the places it makes sense to do so (bullet points above) and then review the situation in the future to see if it makes sense to simplify by removing support in one or more places this transformation capability was added.

In order to know how to reliably transform task payloads from one format to the other, the first step is to work out how to transform a single real-world docker-worker task the equivalent generic-worker task, and make sure it works. That is what this github issue is for.

```

The following is an explanation of the transformation that was performed.

1. Give the container a name, because we are going to extract artifacts from it, so after it has run, we need a reference to its name to be able to copy artifacts onto host. I just generated a slug id for the name of the container (`Twy9U8HtRD2X_m_XCahbEQ`), it can be anything though.
1. Since the `osGroups` feature isn't implemented on Linux yet, I’m running with provisionerId/workerType `proj-taskcluster/gw-ci-ubuntu-18-04` which runs task commands as `root`. Since this mounts cache directories as the task user rather than root, I explicity `chown` the cache directory/directories as `root:root`. When we implement `osGroups` feature, we will add the `docker` group to the task, add the scope to allow its use, and we won’t need the `chown` command, and we won’t need to run on `gw-ci-ubuntu-18-04` since tasks won't need to run as root user anymore.
1. We capture the exit code of the docker container, and don’t exit if it fails, so that we can extract artifact files/directories onto host before task completes. We then `exit ${exit_code}`  in the bash script which wraps the docker command so that original exit code is recorded for task command.
1. After task runs, but before exiting with exit code, to extract artifacts from docker container we run a `docker cp` command for each artifact file/directory declared in the payload.
1. We delete the docker container we created after extracting what we need - although technically not needed, as generic-worker cleans up the task user after the task completes anyway. However, explicitly doing so provides greater clearity about intent.
1. Caches are mounted with `-v` options of `docker run` command.
1. In order for the task commands to have network connectivity to the taskcluster-proxy service started by generic-worker, we add `--add-host=taskcluster:127.0.0.1 --net=host` to the docker run command so that name resolution succeeds.
1. Every environment variable declared in payload is passed into docker run command via `-e <envVar>=<value>` arguments. In addition, the docker-worker managed env vars (except for `TASKCLUSTER_WORKER_LOCATION` - see next point) are also passed through (`RUN_ID`, `TASKCLUSTER_PROXY_URL`, `TASKCLUSTER_ROOT_URL`, `TASK_ID`).
1. `TASKCLUSTER_WORKER_LOCATION` seems to be broken in worker-runner since https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/pull/3686 so we may need to fix that. Decision task can however survive without `TASKCLUSTER_WORKER_LOCATION`.
1. Payload property artifacts has slightly different format under generic-worker (list, not dictionary) - so the artifact object is transformed into a list.
1. Payload property caches feature of docker-worker is mapped to mounts feature of generic-worker, again with slightly different syntax.
1. When docker image is a reference to an image on a docker registry, this reference can be used directly in the `docker run` command as in this case. If the docker payload instead uses a different format to specify docker image (such as a task artifact for a `docker load` command) then we’ll need to transform that slightly differently. This task doesn't cover that case.
1. docker-worker scopes for using caches need to be converted to the equivalent generic-worker scopes to mount the cache under generic-worker.

issue.title: "certificate has expired" sentry alerts for github service
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Sentry issue: https://sentry.io/organizations/mozilla/issues/3555315507/?project=6459385

Exception "certificate has expired" being raised by github service when trying to fetch live log of a task.

**Expected behavior**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen. -->

**Taskcluster version**
Sentry reports this started in taskcluster release 44.20.0.

**Screenshots**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/190790/196697296-27e61dfd-d7fe-4969-b554-5fbd781e1932.png)

**Additional context**
An abbreviated log was added to the github checks output that contained the last lines of the log in release 44.20.0. This retrieved the task log from task artifact `public/logs/live.log`. While the task is running, this artifact will redirect to a live http feed on the worker, which in the case of docker-worker, will be a url with a hostname provided by the stateless dns service. Docker worker configures these hostnames to be valid for the [max run time of the task](https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/blob/ec95016e24808759f3df3db5b6173fc6371a76e7/workers/docker-worker/src/task.js#L790). Under normal operation, the task will complete within the max run time, and replace the live log artifact with a redirect artifact to the backing log. However, since there is no leniency in the expiration of the DNS record, presumably if the livelog url is queried immediately after the expiration of the dns record, but before docker worker has had the chance to upload the backing log and publish the redirect artifact for the livelog, the request will result in an expired certificate. This could also happen if docker-worker hangs for some reason, and does not publish the backing log.

In all cases it is probably desirable to only fetch the log once the task has completed, which is perhaps already the case. In this case, fetching the backing log is desirable, since it should contain the entire log, and only exist if the task has completed. This also avoids that the github service makes active connections to running workers, but instead retrieves artifacts directly from artifact storage (currently, aws s3). Live logs are really only meant to serve users directly, rather than backend services.

pull_request.title: Generic worker docker image
pull_request.body:
Build was using incorrect Dockerfile for the generic worker.

Manually rebuilt and pushed latest `taskcluster/generic-worker:v44.22`.

The only reason it was working locally is because `build` directive was building it each time it started. Now it is moved to `dev` config.

comment.body:
This isn't going to be any good - request npm module has been deprecated for years, and so let's not add it into the mix.

Looks like there is some reworking of the underlying http library ongoing in https://github.com/matrix-org/matrix-js-sdk/pull/2719 so presumably, this will be fixed in a future release. Just seems to be a bad release. Let's wait it out until there is a good release without this issue, where a workaround isn't needed.

pull_request.title: Add build-essential to ubuntu 18.04 and upgrade go and TC versions to latest

review.body:
Thanks for this Boris!

I have some thoughts:

1) It might be that we can remove go in the base image, since our tasks install it. I wonder if the linking problem that we had was because of something that was getting picked up from the go1.18.1 host installation, that conflicted with the go1.19.2 installation of the task. We can talk about this, as there are arguments on both sides worth exploring.
2) Maybe we don't need build-essential, but just gcc - although maybe also nice to have a comprehensive set of tools by default. Again it is quite a nuanced issue, because on one hand it is nice to have reasonable defaults for installed tools, but on the other hand it encourages tasks not to declare dependencies and pin them, so system updates can break user tasks.
3) There is an update to a relman-specific image set, which probably isn't used by the taskcluster project. That is probably a good thing, we just need to make sure we let the team (Release Management - relman) know that we are patching their base images, and keep an eye on their tasks, to see if they start failing after this change.
4) For each of the bootstrap scripts that have been updated, we should build the new machine images (run `imageset.sh` script) so that the latest version in the repository is consistent with the live images. I think this is done for `generic-worker-ubuntu-20-04` but perhaps not for the other image sets yet?

Anyway this is a great start, and I'm really happy to see you were able to build new images successfully. Let's discuss the options for the above points when we next meet up.

Thanks Boris!

review.body:
Thanks Katie!

I see in the docs:
```
  # By default, redirects won’t be applied if there’s a file
  # with the same path as the one defined in the `from` property.
  # Setting `force` to `true` will make the redirect rule
  # take precedence over any existing files.
  force = true
```

Is that definitely the case here? Is there a folder which has the same name?

I'm approving (sorry for delay!) because I can't imagine it does any harm, and hopefully it will fix it! If it does fix it, it might be nice to later add a toml comment to explain why it is needed. Thanks!
